<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adverbs-and-adverb-phrases-position-->
<h1>Adverbs and adverb phrases: position</h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We can put adverbs and adverb phrases at the front, in the middle or at the end of a clause.</p><p class="p"><span class="target"/>The front position of the clause is the first item in the clause:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Suddenly</b> I felt afraid.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Yesterday</b> detectives arrested a man and a woman in connection with the murder.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">The end position of the clause is the last item in the clause:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Why do you always have to eat <b class="b">so fast</b>?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">The mid position is between the subject and the main verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Apples <b class="b">always</b> taste best when you pick them straight off the tree.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">Where there is more than one verb, mid position means after the first auxiliary verb or after a modal verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The government has <b class="b">occasionally</b> been forced to change its mind.</i> (after the first auxiliary verb)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You can <b class="b">definitely never</b> predict what will happen.</i> (after a modal verb)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We mightn’t <b class="b">ever</b> have met.</i> (after the modal verb and before the auxiliary verb)</p></blockquote><p class="p">In questions, mid position is between the subject and the main verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Do you <b class="b">ever</b> think about living there?</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">Adverbs usually come after the main verb <i class="i">be</i>, except in emphatic clauses:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She<b class="b">’s always</b> late for everything.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">When <i class="i">be</i> is emphasised, the adverb comes before the verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Why should I have gone to see Madonna? I <b class="b">never was</b> a fan of hers.</i> (emphatic)</p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/adverb-phrases">Adverb phrases </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be#be__3"><i class="i">Be</i> as a main verb </a> </p></li></ul></div><div class="section_anchor" id="types-of-adverbs-and-their-positions"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Types of adverbs and their positions</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p">Different types of adverbs go in different places.</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">type</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">position</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">example</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">manner</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go in end position.</p><p class="p">They sometimes go in mid position if the adverb is not the most important part of the clause or if the object is very long.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She ate <b class="b">quickly</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <b class="b">quickly</b> ate her dinner and ran out.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">place</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go in end position.</p><p class="p">They sometimes go in front position, especially in writing.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Can you come over <b class="b">here</b>?</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We’ll be at that table <b class="b">there</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Here</b> she sat.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Outside</b>, there was a small pond.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">time</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go in end position.</p><p class="p">They sometimes go in front position especially if we want to emphasise the adverb.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I’m flying to Edinburgh <b class="b">tomorrow</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Today</b>, I’m going to clean the house.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">duration</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go in end position.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I’m not staying <b class="b">long</b>.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">frequency</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go in mid position.</p><p class="p">They sometimes go in front position.</p><p class="p">They can also go in end position.</p><p class="p"><i class="i">Always, ever and never</i> do not usually go in front position.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <b class="b">often</b> have friends to stay.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">usually</b> get up late on weekends.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I could <b class="b">never</b> swim fast.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Sometimes</b> she wore a woollen hat.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We don’t see them <b class="b">very often</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Never I could swim fast</s>.</p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">degree</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">Really, very, quite</i> usually go in mid position.</p><p class="p"><i class="i">A lot</i> and <i class="i">a bit</i> usually go in end position.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I <b class="b">really</b> like those pink flowers.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We go to Ireland <b class="b">a lot</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I’d <b class="b">just</b> like to change things a bit.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">focusing</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go in mid position.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He <b class="b">simply</b> walked out without saying a word.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">certainty or obligation</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">Some go in mid position: <i class="i">probably, possibly, certainly</i>.</p><p class="p">Others go in front position: <i class="i">maybe, perhaps</i> or in end positions after a comma.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">It’ll <b class="b">probably</b> rain.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Maybe</b> Nick will know the answer.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Can I get you a drink, or something to eat, <b class="b">perhaps</b>?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">viewpoint</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go outside the clause, often at the beginning.</p><p class="p">They can sometimes go in mid position, especially in formal writing.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Personally</b>, I’d rather not go out.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">This must, <b class="b">frankly</b>, be the craziest idea anyone has ever had.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">evaluative</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">They usually go outside the clause, often at the beginning.</p><p class="p">They can sometimes go in mid position.</p><p class="p">In informal speaking they can go in end position.</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Unfortunately</b>, I forgot my swimming costume so I had to sit on the side and watch.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We have <b class="b">stupidly</b> forgotten the tickets.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">They missed the bus, <b class="b">apparently</b>.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="manner-place-and-time"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Manner, place and time</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p">Adverbs of manner, place and time usually come in end position:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">He played <b class="b">brilliantly</b>.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">If the verb has an object, the adverb comes after the object:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[verb]</span><span class="rb">made</span></span> <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[object]</span><span class="rb">a decision</span></span> <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[adverb]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">quickly</b></span></span> then left.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">When there is more than one of the three types of adverb together, they usually go in the order: manner, place, time:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">You start off <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[manner]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">slowly</b></span></span> <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[time]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">in the beginning</b></span></span>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s"><i class="i">You start off in the beginning slowly</i></s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">James played <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[manner] [place]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">brilliantly in the match on</b></span></span> <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[time]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">Saturday</b></span></span>.</i> (preferred to <i class="i">James played brilliantly on Saturday in the match</i>.)</p></blockquote><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">We don’t put adverbs between the verb and the object:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">She <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[verb]</span><span class="rb">plays</span></span> <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[object]</span><span class="rb">the piano</span></span> <span class="ruby"><span class="rt">[adverb]</span><span class="rb"><b class="b">really well</b></span></span>. I’ve heard her.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">She plays really well the piano</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I don’t watch the TV <b class="b">very often</b>.</i></p></blockquote></div></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="evaluative-and-viewpoint"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Evaluative and viewpoint</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p">Adverbs indicating the attitude and point of view of the speaker or writer usually go at the beginning. These adverbs are called sentence adverbs <span class="target"/>because they refer to the whole sentence or utterance:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Actually</b>, I think the meeting is on Wednesday, not Thursday.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Obviously</b>, we can’t tell you the result but we can give you an indication.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="position-with-here-and-there"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Position with <i class="i">here</i> and <i class="i">there</i></h2></div><div class="content"><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">If the subject is a pronoun (<i class="i">it/he/she/you</i> etc.), it comes directly after the adverbs <i class="i">here</i> and <i class="i">there</i>. If the subject is a noun, it comes directly after the verb:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Here</b> she is.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Here is she</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">There</b> it goes.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">There goes it</s>.</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Here</b> comes the bus.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">Here the bus comes</s>.</p></blockquote></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/adverbs-types">Adverbs: types </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_b' class='am-default '>
</div>

</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/amount-of-number-of-or-quantity-of"><i>Amount of</i>, <i>number of</i> or <i>quantity of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/any-more-or-anymore"><i>Any more</i> or <i>anymore</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/apart-from-or-except-for"><i>Apart from</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arise-or-rise"><i>Arise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/around-or-round"><i>Around</i> or <i>round</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arouse-or-rouse"><i>Arouse</i> or <i>rouse</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-or-like"><i>As</i> or <i>like</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since"><i>As</i>, <i>because</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-when-or-while"><i>As</i>, <i>when</i> or <i>while</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/been-or-gone"><i>Been</i> or <i>gone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/begin-or-start"><i>Begin</i> or <i>start</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beside-or-besides"><i>Beside</i> or <i>besides</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/between-or-among"><i>Between</i> or <i>among</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/born-or-borne"><i>Born</i> or <i>borne</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/bring-take-and-fetch"><i>Bring</i>, <i>take</i> and <i>fetch</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can-could-or-may"><i>Can</i>, <i>could</i> or <i>may</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i>Classic</i> or <i>classical?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/come-or-go"><i>Come</i> or <i>go?</i></a>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consider-or-regard"><i>Consider</i> or <i>regard</i>?</a>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consist-comprise-or-compose"><i>Consist</i>, <i>comprise</i> or <i>compose</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/content-or-contents"><i>Content</i> or <i>contents?</i></a>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/different-from-different-to-or-different-than"><i>Different from</i>, <i>different to</i> or <i>different than</i>?</a>
</li>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do-or-make"><i>Do</i> or <i>make</i>?</a>

<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/down-downwards-or-downward"><i>Down, downwards or <i>downward?</i></i></a>

<li class="section">
<a>Words, sentences and clauses</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-words-clauses-and-sentences">about words, clauses and sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-and-as-expressions"><i>as</i> and <i>as</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/comparing-and-contrasting">comparing and contrasting</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/conditionals-and-wishes">conditionals and wishes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/linking-words-and-expressions">linking words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/questions-and-negative-sentences">questions and negative sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/relative-clauses">relative clauses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/reported-speech">reported speech</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/so-and-such"><i>so</i> and <i>such</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-formation">word formation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-order-and-focus">word order and focus</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/discourse-markers">discourse markers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/emphasising-and-downtoning">emphasising and downtoning</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking">speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions"><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality">modals and modality</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">
